content:
We got a suggestion from a user for a feature that to me personally sounds super useful - being able to bind certain streams to numbers, so that each such stream can be navigated to with a keyboard shortcut with the number - for example Ctr+1, Ctr+2 etc.

Any thoughts on whether others agree with this being something we want, and if so, what the keyboard shortcut should be?

Does this conflict with org switching in the desktop app? (I don't use the desktop app, so I don't remember)

Seems like something useful overall :)
I can get to most streams pretty quickly with q, and I wouldn't want a binding to interleaved views.

Steve Howell (showell) said:

I can get to most streams pretty quickly with q, and I wouldn't want a binding to interleaved views.

Hmm true, but I imagine that if someone has only a couple of streams that they use very intensively, it would be an overkill to go through stream filtering every time to move between them - compared to just hitting Ctr+1, Ctr+2 to super-quickly switch between them

Wesley Aptekar-Cassels said:

Does this conflict with org switching in the desktop app? (I don't use the desktop app, so I don't remember)

On macOS, those are bound to ⌘1, ⌘2, etc.
I don't have a Linux or Windows machine to check those.

Mateusz Mandera said:

Steve Howell (showell) said:

I can get to most streams pretty quickly with q, and I wouldn't want a binding to interleaved views.

Hmm true, but I imagine that if someone has only a couple of streams that they use very intensively, it would be an overkill to go through stream filtering every time to move between them - compared to just hitting Ctr+1, Ctr+2 to super-quickly switch between them

The q navigation respects pinning.
I don't see this as being a feature that would add much, in addition to having the conflict with the desktop app, so I'd thank the user for their feedback and move on.

Hey guys, just wanted to chime in with my 2 cents.

I heavily use one or two streams at a time, and most of the time I'm bouncing between topics. Ideally, when I use apps a lot, I like to use shortcut keys as much as possible, so that I'm basically just using my lizard brain to use the tools, (in this case navigating to the right stream/topic) and reserving my exec center for the tasks that need it (composing messages). Often when I am using Zulip, I have a thought in my head, or a response, and I'd like to get it written out in the right location without using the executive center in my brain.

For my case, ideally there would be a global keybinding that quickly places me somewhere I could type a few letters of the topic, hit enter and start typing my message. I'm aware there is a path to doing this using key commands only, but they are conditional (you cant be in edit mode) and they require a specific order. This means that in practice, I have to engage my executive center in order to find the right topic to sent the message in. And it's not for lack of trying. This may sound a bit dramatic, but as someone who works with ADD, I'm particularly sensitive to this while working,

@Alexx Henry thanks for the feedback! Can you talk a bit more about the situation you're in when you want such a keybinding? I can imagine c doing what you want, but I don't think I have enough context on the situation to be sure.

(That opens the compose box with the current stream and focus in the topic input box).
Is the idea that you want Zulip's autocomplete in the topic box to consider potential existing topics in other streams that you're subscribed to?

I think this is one reason that Alexx Henry doesn't find c alone to be a solution:

Alexx Henry said:

I'm aware there is a path to doing this using key commands only, but they are conditional (you cant be in edit mode) and they require a specific order.

It won't work when you're inside the compose box, because it'll type a literal "c" instead.

I think one habit I have in using Zulip (and @Alexx Henry, you might or might not find this helpful) is that before typing a navigation command like c or n or t, I'll hit the Up or Down arrow key a couple of times.

This has the effect of closing the compose box, if it's open but empty. And if it's already closed, it's basically harmless, just moves the blue-box cursor a couple of messages.

For me, I think it isn't common that I'll have the compose box open and have text in it, unless I'm actively thinking about an in-progress message. But it is common to have the compose box open and empty. So this is a way of resetting the state to "compose box is closed", without first looking to see if it is.

Hmm, and perhaps relatedly: just after sending that message, I noticed that I hit the arrow keys to move the cursor up and down a few messages.

I think that's probably also a habit -- probably I often do that after sending a message, if I don't intend to immediately send another. That's also a way of resetting the state to "compose box empty", so that navigation commands are available.

Thanks @Tim Abbott

I'll speak first to what I want to acomplish: Often I have a thought in my head, and I want to quickly get it out and into a message in the appropriate topic. What I would like is for a method to quickly access the target topic, even if I only have a fuzzy idea of what it's called.

@Greg Price 's comment is correct. Because c is modal, it often requires c escape c, which takes me out of the zone. I do use vim, so i'm ok with modal programs, but the bigger issue i have with c is that it requres me to be in a specific stream.

Getting to the stream is also modal, and I think the combination of q text t t text, etc... in practial use winds up being too high friction for me to use consistantly.
a non-modal keybinding that was like c but that would seach across all topics would acutally solve my problem, but I'm sure there are many ways to acheive this.

Thanks for the helpful feedback!

Alexx Henry said:

I do use vim, so i'm ok with modal programs, but the bigger issue i have with c is that it requres me to be in a specific stream.

One thing you can do is hit c -- or if you're already in the compose box, then skip that step -- and then go and edit the field that says what stream you're sending to.

The stream and topic fields are both editable, just like the message content is.

You can get to that field with the mouse, or with normal keyboard UI navigation by hitting Shift+Tab a couple of times.

Greg Price said:

You can get to that field with the mouse, or with normal keyboard UI navigation by hitting Shift+Tab a couple of times.

What kind of monster uses a mouse? ;)
(To be clear: I don't think this is obvious!)
@Greg Price the shift-tab thing is not bad.

Honestly if there were a non-modal method to quickly nav to a stream, then I think hitting c once I'm there is totally reasonable, and b/c I would be getting there the same way, the modality of c wouldnt matter.

I know it seems like I'm being nit picky, but I promise I'm putting in the effort to try to make it work for me, and for some reason hitting q, then somethimes realizing I need to hit escape then q, then the rest.. it almost always winds up taking me out of the zone.
also, I often find myself not being able to do an escape sequence that gets me to be able to use q. I'm sure i'm in some other mode, but I havent been able to identify the pattern yet.
Do you ever try using Ctrl+K for this purpose? I wonder if that one works for you.
That one deliberately works even if you have the compose box open. It opens the search bar, and one of the things you can do there is go to a stream or a topic.

I think the original idea when we picked that binding for that functionality was that it'd be a form of global quick navigation -- basically exactly what you're looking for here, I think.

I'm not sure we've entirely realized that vision as things stand, but if not then perhaps that's a direction to work in.

I find Ctrl+K to be too everthing but the kitchen sink for it to be usefull for a rapid navigation. I like the idea... It's what I used to use in Slack, and what works well in Monday, but I haven't had luck here.
